items.title: B.C. man sentenced to life in prison for stabbing death of young mother
items.summary_auto: A B.C. Supreme Court Justice has delivered the sentence for Zain Wood who was convicted of of  first-degree murder in the stabbing of 22-year-old, Prince George, B.C., mother Isabelle Thomas in front of her two children in 2023.

items.title: Labelling Palestine Action a terrorist group was unlawful, Britain’s High Court rules
items.summary_auto: Britain's High Court says the U.K. government acted unlawfully when it designated the protest group Palestine Action as a terrorist organization. But the fate of protesters arrested under the Terrorism Act still hangs in the balance.

items.title: Seasonique, Seasonale birth control pills recalled over possible missing blister card
items.summary_auto: Teva Canada is recalling two lots of Seasonique and one lot of Seasonale prescription birth control pills as a precaution after the company received a complaint about a package missing an entire blister card of pills, Health Canada says.

items.title: The ‘Arc de Trump’ | About That
items.summary_auto: Andrew Chang explains why U.S. President Donald Trump wants to build a 250-foot-high 'Independence Arch' in Washington, D.C., and why it’s under heavy scrutiny. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images

items.title: Manitoba issues blanket measles warning for 5 southern RMs, says fans were exposed at Jets game
items.summary_auto: Manitoba saw 44 confirmed cases of measles during the first week of February, as well as an exposure at the Feb. 4 Winnipeg Jets game, the province's latest measles reports say.

items.title: Canada, Denmark deepen defence ties after Greenland annexation threat
items.summary_auto: Canada and Denmark have signed a new defence co-operation agreement aimed at strengthening Arctic security amid lingering tensions over U.S. annexation threats toward Greenland. The pact enhances collaboration on surveillance and joint operations but does not go beyond existing NATO Article 5 commitments.

items.title: Mexico probing whether B.C. mining company was responsible in kidnapping of its workers
items.summary_auto: Mexico’s Attorney General’s Office is investigating whether a Canadian mining company holds any responsibility in the suspected cartel kidnapping of 10 of its workers, President Claudia Sheinbaum said Friday.

items.title: Former minister Freeland violated election rules during 2024 byelection, watchdog finds
items.summary_auto: Former deputy prime minister and cabinet minister Chrystia Freeland violated election rules during a 2024 byelection, the Commissioner of Canada Elections said on Friday.

items.title: What we know — and don't — about the guns used in the Tumbler Ridge, B.C., shooting
items.summary_auto: Three days after one of the deadliest mass shootings in Canada's history, it's still unclear how the shooter, who had a history of mental illness, got hold of the guns recovered at the two crime scenes.

items.title: Indian man pleads guilty in New York over alleged plot against Sikh separatist
items.summary_auto: An Indian man pleaded guilty on Friday to ‌U.S. criminal charges that he orchestrated a failed Indian government-backed plot to kill a Sikh separatist in New York ‌City, in connection with what U.S. and Canadian authorities have called a broader effort to target Indian dissidents.

items.title: Democrats launching probe into Trump, Lutnick links with Moroun after Gordie Howe bridge threat
items.summary_auto: Democrats in Washington say they’re launching an investigation into the Trump administration and its links to the wealthy owner of the Ambassador Bridge after the U.S. president threatened to block the opening of the competing Gordie Howe Bridge earlier this week.

items.title: Supreme Court nullifies Liberal MP's election win by a single vote in Montreal-area riding
Ex-Israeli PM Ehud Barak apologizes for maintaining Epstein relationship after 2008 conviction
items.summary_auto: Former Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak has apologized for his yearslong friendship with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein that included regular correspondence and multiple visits to the disgraced financier's Manhattan apartment, as well as visit to his private island.

items.title: The facts about Iran protest flags
items.summary_auto: Different versions of the Iranian flag have appeared at protests around the world. Here are the facts about what each of them represent.

items.title: Deal between Ontario and Diageo panned by mayor, union in Amherstburg as plant prepares to close
items.summary_auto: Ontario will keep Crown Royal on the shelves in the province's liquor stores, it says, after parent company Diageo agreed to almost $23 million in spending in the alcohol and agriculture sectors.

items.title: Oscar-nominated director Jafar Panahi says he will return to Iran despite looming arrest
items.summary_auto: Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi says he plans to return to Iran after Oscar season is over, despite the looming threat of his arrest amid a government crackdown on protests that has killed thousands and detained many more.

items.title: Oshawa Generals apologize after asking fans to shower before games
items.summary_auto: The OHL's Oshawa Generals have apologized after asking fans to shower before attending games. The junior ice hockey team's director of ticket sales and service sent out on email this week asking fans to shower if they went to the gym "or did something that produced body odour."

items.title: Family of Portapique victims send message of hope, healing to Tumbler Ridge
items.summary_auto: It was almost six years ago that Tammy Oliver-McCurdie lost her younger sister, brother-in-law and 17-year-old niece in Nova Scotia, all of them victims of the deadliest mass shooting in modern Canadian history.

items.title: A Ukrainian athlete was banned for his helmet. How does the IOC enforce its rules on political statements?
FBI releases suspect description, new details in Nancy Guthrie disappearance
items.summary_auto: Investigators in Arizona want residents near Nancy Guthrie's home to share surveillance footage of suspicious cars or people they may have noticed in the month before she disappeared.

items.title: Winnipeg man calls for improved patient safety after mother, 94, attacked in hospital
items.summary_auto: A Winnipeg man whose mother, 94, was assaulted by another patient at St. Boniface Hospital says hospitals need to re-evaluate how patients are paired in shared rooms.

items.title: Rural hospitals might buckle under the pressure if measles spread continues: doctor
items.summary_auto: If the measles outbreak continues to get worse, rural health-care facilities in southwestern Manitoba might not have the capacity to house all the sick, according to a Neepawa family physician.

items.title: Nova Scotians’ paper health records being trucked to Ontario to be digitized
items.summary_auto: The union representing health-care administrative professionals has filed a grievance over the contracting out of union work.

items.title: What are minor hockey leagues in Nova Scotia doing to prevent hazing?
items.summary_auto: Four youth players on a Truro-area team are facing sexual assault charges as part of an ongoing investigation by RCMP. The lead investigator has said more victims are expected to come forward.

items.title: Is your water safe? N.B. lab gave outdated answers
items.summary_auto: Thousands of private well owners in New Brunswick may be finding out they've got a problem that will cost hundreds of dollars to fix, now that New Brunswick has aligned its drinking water guidelines with Health Canada. Updates include a 2019 warning that too much manganese can be harmful to children.

items.title: This X account looked like it belonged to the Tumbler Ridge shooter. It was a hoax
items.summary_auto: A social media account that some initially believed belonged to the Tumbler Ridge shooter turned out to be a fraud — and even briefly fooled a prominent non-profit organization. Disinformation researchers say spreading false claims can be extremely harmful, especially in the wake of tragedies like mass shootings.

items.title: Emerald Fennell's 'Wuthering Heights' is objectively not Wuthering Heights
items.summary_auto: Emerald Fennell liberally reinterprets Emily Brontë's 1847 novel in her new film but seems uninterested — to the point of negligence — in what the beloved British author was trying to say.
